course_title: Foundations of Physiotherapy II: Fundamentals of Examination & Measurement

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze human movement considering basic anatomical, physiological, biomechanical and psychological principles
Observe and accurately record basic features of movement in a systematic manner
Perform basic muscle testing and joint examination methods related to the upper and lower limbs and the trunk
Understand the principles of muscle training and exercise
Appreciate the teaching role of the physiotherapist in clinical practice
Design and teach various exercise methods proficiently
Use ergonomic principles to handle and position patients with safety, comfort and convenience to both the patient/client and the physiotherapist
Apply problem-solving strategies and techniques for simple clinical situations
Understand the principles of muscle training, plan and manage individual exercise programs and exercise classes

assessments.due_date:
20/01/2026 8:00 am

This exam will run between 8am and 2pm. Please see Blackboard for exam schedule.
assessments.task_description:
This practical examination will cover all material taught relating to fundamentals of physiotherapy assessment for the lower limb, upper limb, neck and trunk.

Students will be required to perform a series of physical examination techniques (including corresponding measurements where relevant). The emphasis of this examination is on the effective and safe performance of these procedures, although examiners will also question students about the theoretical underpinnings of these techniques. 

This exam is worth 30% of the overall course grade and is a must-pass component. The overall pass mark for this assessment task is 55%.

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

In this course the recording of an assessment (oral/practical) performance has been waived, a record of student performance will be taken by other means such as detailed written notes that can be referred to if a remark is required at a later date.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

This exam will run between 8am and 2pm. Please see Blackboard for exam schedule.
assessments.task_description:
During this practical examination students will be required to assess and prescribe therapeutic exercises, and demonstrate PNF techniques. All practical skills and theoretical knowledge from the course pertaining to therapeutic exercise and PNF will be examinable. 

This exam is worth 30% of the overall course grade and is a must-pass component. The overall pass mark for this assessment task is 55%.

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

In this course the recording of an assessment (oral/practical) performance has been waived, a record of student performance will be taken by other means such as detailed written notes that can be referred to if a remark is required at a later date.

assessments.assessment_title: End of Semester Theory Exam - All content
assessments.task_description:
This end of semester theory examination will include all of the content covered in PHTY7803. It will be a closed book, online (Inspera) examination, held in-person, on-campus during the end of semester examination period. It may contain multiple choice, short answer, problem solving, and essay-style questions. The exam will run for a total of 130 minutes, including 10 minutes planning/reading time.

This exam is a must-pass component of the course and is worth 40% of the overall course grade. The pass mark for this exam is 55%.

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 4(05 Jan - 01 Feb)
learning_activities.topic:
Assessment of lower limb, upper limb and spine function

This course contains a combination of i) online pre-recorded lectures for independent, self-paced learning, and ii) in-person face-to-face lectures to foster collaboration and clinical reasoning skills. There are approximately 15 hours of lectures scheduled per week, as indicated on the course schedule on Blackboard. Content provides foundational information about physical examination assessments for upper limb, lower limb and spine function.
learning_activities.topic_title: Assessment of lower limb, upper limb and spine function
learning_activities.topic_description: Assessment of lower limb, upper limb and spine function This course contains a combination of i) online pre-recorded lectures for independent, self-paced learning, and ii) in-person face-to-face lectures to foster collaboration and clinical reasoning skills. There are approximately 15 hours of lectures scheduled per week, as indicated on the course schedule on Blackboard. learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 4(05 Jan - 01 Feb)
learning_activities.topic:
Assessment of lower limb, upper limb and spine function

Students will attend numerous 2-3 hour in-person practical sessions on campus throughout the course to learn and gain feedback on practical physical examination skills. These practical sessions will feature inquiry-based learning and small group discussions to explore foundational assessments of upper limb, lower limb and spine function. To prepare effectively, students must review the online self-paced content (e.g. skills videos, lectures) and associated preparatory tasks prior to attending. As this is a small-group, interactive experience, it will not be recorded.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 4(05 Jan - 01 Feb)
learning_activities.topic:
Principles of Exercise Assessment and Prescription

This course contains a combination of i) online pre-recorded lectures for independent, self-paced learning, and ii) in-person face-to-face lectures to foster collaboration and clinical reasoning skills. There are approximately 15 hours of lectures scheduled per week, as indicated on the course schedule on Blackboard. Content provides foundational information about exercise assessments and management spanning musculoskeletal, cardiovascular and sensori-motor systems, and PNF.
